title: Fate of California's auto standards will come down to Senate battle

titles: Fate of California's auto standards will come down to Senate battle

constructiveness_reason: This story informs readers about a significant shift in environmental regulation policy and its potential implications. It provides useful context about the relationship between federal and state regulations, which can help readers understand the broader system within which these decisions are made.

title: Tariffs To Take a Bite Out of Apple's Results
snippets:
Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook said the Trump administration’s tariffs, if they remain at their current levels, will cost Apple about $900 million in the current quarter that runs through June. 

During the company’s quarterly earnings call Thursday, Cook said a majority of iPhones sold in the U.S. this quarter will come from India, rather than China, with iPad, Mac, Apple Watch, and other products coming mostly from Vietnam.

The comments come amid concerns the company could be particularly hurt by trade tensions with China, where Apple manufactured an estimated 90% of its products until recently. Most Apple products are exempt from President Trump's 125% "reciprocal" tariffs on Chinese goods, but still affected by the 20% import tax the White House put in place earlier in the year to combat fentanyl trafficking, Cook noted.

Cook also warned the impact of tariffs to Apple's results could change, given the company is “uncertain of potential future actions” the administration could take. Trump has said he expects tariffs on China “will come down substantially” in trade negotiations but not drop to zero. 

Apple reported fiscal second-quarter revenue and earnings that surpassed analysts’ expectations, with higher-than-expected iPhone sales.

Shares of Apple fell about 4% in extended trading. The stock was down 15% for 2025 through Thursday’s close.
titles: Tariffs To Take a Bite Out of Apple's Results
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook announced during the company's quarterly earnings call that the Trump administration's tariffs could cost the company approximately $900 million in the current quarter. Cook highlighted that a majority of iPhones sold in the U.S. this quarter will be manufactured in India, not China, with other products primarily coming from Vietnam, in response to trade tensions with China. Despite most Apple products being exempt from Trump's "reciprocal" tariffs on Chinese goods, a 20% import tax aimed at combating fentanyl trafficking still affects Apple. Cook expressed uncertainty about
constructiveness_reason: This story informs and contextualizes the impact of tariffs on Apple's operations, providing useful insights for the reader. It also reports on Apple's response to the trade tensions, such as manufacturing more iPhones in India and other products in Vietnam. However, it does not highlight any clear progress or solutions, which is why it doesn't score higher.

title: Apple Delivers Better-Than-Expected iPhone Sales, Announces $100B Buyback
snippets:
Apple (AAPL) reported fiscal second-quarter revenue and earnings that surpassed analysts’ expectations, with higher-than-expected iPhone sales.

The iPhone maker reported revenue of $95.4 billion, up 5% year-over-year and above the analyst consensus from Visible Alpha. Net income of $24.78 billion, or $1.65 per share, compared to $23.64 billion, or $1.53 per share, a year earlier, topping Wall Street’s estimates. 

The gains came as Apple's iPhone sales climbed 2% to $46.84 billion, ahead of projections, while Mac sales rose 7% to $7.95 billion, and iPad sales jumped 15% to $6.4 billion. The company's services revenue improved 12% to $26.65, just under expectations of $26.71 billion.

Apple also said its board authorized a $100 billion share repurchase program and increased its dividend by 4% to 26 cents per share.

However, shares slipped in extended trading Thursday as CEO Tim Cook told investors during the company's earnings call that tariffs, if kept at their current levels, would increase Apple’s costs by about $900 million in the current quarter running through June. Cook said he expects Apple's total revenue to grow by low- to mid-single digits in the current quarter, compared to Street projections of about 4%.

Cook warned the impact of tariffs could change, given the company is “uncertain of potential future actions.” The majority of iPhones sold in the U.S. this quarter will come from India rather than China, Cook said, with iPad, Mac, Apple Watch, and other products coming mostly from Vietnam. 

The results come as several analysts have warned the company could be particularly hurt by trade tensions with China, where Apple until recently manufactured an estimated 90% of its products. President Donald Trump has said he expects tariffs on China “will come down substantially” but not drop to zero. To help mitigate some risk, Apple is reportedly planning to move the assembly of all iPhones it sells in the U.S. to India by the end of 2026. 

Apple shares slid about 4% in after-hours trading. The stock was down 15% for 2025 through Thursday’s close.

This article has been updated since it was first published to include additional information and reflect more recent share price values.
titles: Apple Delivers Better-Than-Expected iPhone Sales, Announces $100B Buyback
summary: Apple reported a fiscal second-quarter revenue of $95.4 billion, a 5% increase from the previous year, surpassing analyst expectations. Net income rose to $24.78 billion, with earnings per share at $1.65, also beating Wall Street forecasts. iPhone sales saw a 2% increase to $46.84 billion, while Mac and iPad sales grew by 7% and 15%, respectively. However, despite these gains, Apple's shares fell approximately 4% in after-hours trading, influenced by CEO Tim Cook's warnings about the potential $900 million cost impact of tariffs in the current quarter. Cook also highlighted a strategic shift i
constructiveness_reason: This story does a good job of providing useful information about Apple's financial performance, including details about sales of different products and the company's buyback plan. However, it still falls short of a higher score because it doesn't provide enough context or analysis about why shares fell despite the positive performance, and it doesn't highlight any innovative solutions or strategies.

title: Exercise Can Prevent Cognitive Decline, Even When Energy Is Low
snippets: Mizzou researchers discover that exercise enhances brain health, even when the liver’s ability to produce ketones is compromised. We all know that exercise benefits the body, but what about the brain? A new study from the University of Missouri suggests that physical activity may be essential for maintaining mental sharpness, even when the brain is [...]
titles: Exercise Can Prevent Cognitive Decline, Even When Energy Is Low
summary: University of Missouri researchers found that exercise boosts brain health and can prevent cognitive decline. This benefit occurs even when the liver's ability to produce ketones, which are crucial for brain energy, is compromised. The study underscores the importance of physical activity in maintaining mental sharpness, highlighting exercise as a key factor in brain health regardless of the body's ketone production levels.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive because it provides actionable insights for readers about the importance of exercise for brain health. It also provides a deeper understanding of the role of ketones in brain energy and how exercise can benefit brain health even when ketone production is compromised.

constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it reports on a significant progress in Alzheimer's research, which could lead to a solution for preventing the disease. It also provides awareness about the role of the tau protein in Alzheimer's disease.

title: Scientists Discover Nature’s Secret to Healthy Longevity
snippets: Researchers at Bar-Ilan University reveal protein changes linked to longevity throughout mammalian evolution. Over the past several decades, human lifespan has steadily increased. However, this progress has also led to a growing proportion of the population suffering from age-related diseases such as cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, and diabetes. Extending both lifespan and healthspan, the period of [...]
titles: Scientists Discover Nature’s Secret to Healthy Longevity
summary: Researchers at Bar-Ilan University have identified protein changes that have contributed to increased longevity in mammals over evolutionary history. This discovery is significant in understanding how lifespan has extended in humans, alongside the rise in age-related diseases like cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, and diabetes. The study aims to enhance both lifespan and healthspan, the duration of life spent in good health.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive because it provides useful information about the role of protein changes in longevity and age-related diseases. However, it lacks specific actionable insights or solutions for the reader, hence the slightly lower score.

title: Brain signals can change the gut microbiome in as little as 2 hours
snippets: We have known for years that the gut microbiome can alter brain function, but now research in mice is suggesting that the opposite is also true – that the brain modifies gut bacteria
titles: Brain signals can change the gut microbiome in as little as 2 hours

This finding adds to the existing knowledge that the gut microbiome can affect brain function, highlighting the complex interplay between the two.

It also highlights the progress made in this area of research, which could potentially lead to innovative solutions for health issues related to the gut microbiome.

title: Our cells can divide in a completely unexpected way
